Human: Thanks. How many Indians work in manufacturing. And are the work conditions comparable to a sweatshop?

Assistant:
chosen:
India’s government has published two reports on the labor conditions in different sectors of the economy. One by the Ministry of Labor & Employment and another by the Employment and Training Institute. Here are some highlights from those two reports:


Manufacturing workers receive more than Rs.600 per month and form the largest group of employed workers.


Manufacturing workers mostly are employed by SMEs. The average monthly wages vary from Rs.250 - Rs.900 per month.


Sweatshops can be found in:


- Jeans Manufacturing Industry,

- T-shirt Manufacturing,

- Cutlery manufacturing,

- Candle Making,

- Electronic Manufacturing,

- Sports Goods Manufacturing.
rejected: About 42 percent of the total workforce of India are working in manufacturing. Most of the factories are in tier-1 and tier-2 cities. Due to the change in government, workers were paid bonuses due to low productivity in 2018, which is also known as the "Essar case". Wages are among the lowest in the world in India. Most factories are also located in the outskirts of cities, and the workers don’t have access to basic amenities. Sometimes, women workers are victims of sexual harassment by supervisors. Labor rights activists like Human Rights Watch and the International Labor Organization argue that workers don’t have the right to organize unions or protests. These are in violation of the International Labor Organization's (ILO) Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work, which was ratified by India in 1976.
